title: Is every piece of music a “track”? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. The word has different meanings depending on the style of music and the era. When phonograph records first came on the scene, each individual song was sometimes called a track. This was because the needle that etched the sound into the vinyl master could well be described as a “track” - like a track an animal would make. These songs were recorded in mono (not stereo). When Les Paul invented “multitracking” Multitrack recording - Wikipedia, the artists could record first one track, usually bass and drums at once, then “overdub” the second track, which might be vocals, or piano, etc. As tape technology became more sophisticated, more and more tracks could be put on a tape. Typical formats: 2-track stereo, 4-track (Sargent Pepper’s!) Reel-to-reel systems use tape that is 1⁄4, 1⁄2, 1, or 2 inches (6.35, 12.70, 25.40, or 50.80 mm) wide, which normally moves at 3 3⁄4 or 7 1⁄2 inches per second (9.5 or 19.1 cm/s). Right before the industry went to digital (all 0’s and 1’s) the 2-inch 24-track format was pretty standard. Then, when rap and hip hop came along, tracks took on a slightly different meaning. Musicians would compose what we called “musical beds” that rappers could then improvise over. These “beds” were often called “tracks” and much of the musical material came from…ready?…old vinyl records that the DJ would manipulate by hand, grabbing bits and pieces of 1, 2, 3 second musical thoughts, then mixing them in with their own musical ideas. And little by slow, DJ’s left the radio station and (via Jamaica) came out on the dance floor. This music is mostly referred to as EDM, or Electronic Dance Music. I’ll stop here, lest I loose track of my train of thought…

Music is recorded on separate ‘tracks’. In the old days, there was only ONE track called ‘Monaural’. Then two called ‘stereo’ to simulate a 3–d effect. Then came recorders that could overlay more than one track besides the original. In the early 60’s an analog 4 track recorder was state of the art, but was very limiting excepting some very clever manipulations to combine tracks that won’t be changing. Analog mixers and recorders eventually got to where they could have 24 tracks or more. In the digital world, the number of available tracks are almost limitless. So to answer the question, music is recorded and produced on tracks regardless of how they are mixed together in the final form. There are some purists that still aim to get good sound with one microphone and single track recorder.
